Home » Aviation » Airlines current challenges impact tourism, says NANTA President Airlines current challenges impact tourism, says NANTA President On 9:36 pm In Aviation by Okogba Comments 
THE National President of National Association of Nigerian Travel Agencies (NANTA) Mr Bankole Bernard has said the current challenges facing airlines operating in the country have had negative effects on travel agents in the country and impacted tourism. 
Bernard’s declaration came while delivering his welcome address at the 41st Non Elective General Annual Meeting (AGM) with the theme, “Tourism in a Recessed Economy: The Way Forward” held in Lagos. He said the reduction in the number of airlines, both domestic and foreign, operating in Nigeria has led to fewer ticket sales and affected the profit margins of travel agents. 
The NANTA President who enumerated some of the problems affecting airlines to include the inability of foreign airlines to repatriate ticket sales proceeds due to unstable and scarce Foreign Exchange, said this major problem has led to partial withdrawal of some airlines from Nigeria. He also said “ the restriction of some inventories by some airlines like SOTO/SOTI tickets” and the closure of the Abuja Airport , a major hub, are some of the problems the airlines are grappling with. 
These challenges according to him, have “ brought hard and unfriendly business atmosphere to our teeming members, and this scenario presents a huge burden to the association.” 
According to him, “We call on our members to remain strong, resolute and also endeavour to take advantage of every available opportunity in tourism to chart a new course. At our end, this council and the BOT of NANTA will strive to sustain the advocacy to occupy the Nigerian travel and tourism space like it has never been done before.” 
Bernard said “That our nation is in recession today is not the issue but finding a true solution to the various challenges this economic meltdown present to us.”He also said that the 41st AGM had provided members opportunity to discuss the issues and proffer solutions to some if not all the challenges NANTA members are facing.
